{{For|the name of God given by Guru Nanak in the Japji|Ik Onkar}} {{Multiple issues| {{Primary sources|date=August 2018}} {{POV|date=February 2015}} }} {{Infobox religion | name = Eckankar | image = Image:USVA headstone emb-28.svg|thumb|150px | imagewidth = | alt = | caption = The Eckankar "EK" symbol | abbreviation = | type = [[Religious movement]] | main_classification = | orientation = | scripture = Main:''Shariyat-Ki-Sugmad''
Minor:''Autobiography of a Modern Prophet'' etc.{{cite web|url=https://www.eckbooks.org/catalog/Books-3-1.html?ClearCart20UserSession=7f27758e6d997519fffad49def78078a|title=Eckankar Online Bookstore - Books|website=www.eckbooks.org|accessdate=16 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.religionfacts.com/eckankar/texts|title=Eckankar sacred texts|publisher=|accessdate=16 March 2018}} | theology = | polity = | governance = | structure = | leader_title = The Mahanta, the Living ECK Master | leader_name = Harold Klemp | leader_title1 = | leader_name1 = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | fellowships_type = | fellowships = | fellowships_type1 = | fellowships1 = | associations = | area = Mostly worldwide | headquarters = [[Temple of Eck]], [[Chanhassen]], [[Minnesota]] | founder = [[Paul Twitchell]] | founded_date = 1965 | founded_place = [[San Diego]], [[California]]{{cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/116546831/?terms=%22paul+twitchell%22++%22Soul+Travel%22|title=7 Nov 1965, Page 2 - Chula Vista Star-News at Newspapers.com|publisher=|accessdate=16 March 2018}} | separated_from = | parent = | merger = | absorbed = | separations = | merged_into = | defunct = | congregations_type = Centres | congregations = 367+ (Late 1990s){{cite web|url=http://www.religionfacts.com/eckankar/history|title=History of Eckankar|publisher=|accessdate=16 March 2018}} | members = 50,000-500,000{{cite web|url=http://www.religionfacts.com/eckankar|title=Eckankar|publisher=|accessdate=16 March 2018}} | ministers_type = | ministers = | missionaries = | temples = 1 | hospitals = | nursing_homes = | aid = | primary_schools = | secondary_schools = | tertiary = | other_names = | publications = | website = {{official URL}} | footnotes = }} [[File:2013-0718-TempleofEck.jpg|thumb|300px|right|[[Temple of ECK]], Chanhassen, Minnesota]] '''Eckankar''' is a [[religious movement]] founded by [[Paul Twitchell]] in 1965. It is a non-profit religious group with members in over one hundred countries. The spiritual home is the [[Temple of Eck]] in [[Chanhassen]], [[Minnesota]]. Eckankar is not affiliated with any other religious group. The movement teaches simple spiritual exercises, such as singing "''Hu''", called "a love song to God", to experience the Light and Sound of God and recognize the presence of the Holy Spirit."[http://www.eckankar.org/hu.html HU: A Love Song to God]", Eckankar website, last modified 16 Jan. 2016. Retrieved 30 Jan. 2016."This sound develops through ten different aspects ... until it finally becomes Hu, the most sacred of all sounds. This sound Hu is the beginning and end of all sounds ... the echo of bells or gongs gives a typical illustration of the sound Hu. The Supreme Being has been called by various names in different languages, but the mystics have known him as Hu, the natural name, not man-made, the only name of the nameless which all nature constantly proclaims. The sound Hu is most sacred; the mystics of all ages called it Ismi-Azam, the name of the most High, for it is the origin and end of every sound as well as the background of each word. The word Hu is the spirit of all sounds ... This alone is the true name of God, a name that no people and no religion can claim as their own. ... All things and beings exclaim this name of the Lord, for every activity of life expresses distinctly or indistinctly this very sound. ... The mystery of Hu is revealed to the Sufi who journeys through the path of initiation." –Inayat Khan, [http://www.hazrat-inayat-khan.org/php/views.php?h1=11&h2=8 ''The Mysticism of Sound''] / [http://www.soufi-inayat-khan.org/murshid/myst_son/gb_ms08.htm ''Abstract Sound''].[[Hu (Sufism)|Hu]] ==Etymology== The word Eckankar is a transliteration of the phrase [[Ik Onkar]], which is used in [[Sikhism]]."In the literature of the Saints, God is expressed by many words, such as Swami, [[Ik Onkar|Ekankar]], Nirankar, Radhaswami, Akal, Nirala, Anami, Agam, Alakh, Sat Purush, Prabhu, Prabhswami, Hari Ray, Akshar, Parameshwar, Akshar Purush, etc. ... [[Ik Onkar|Ekankar]] means the “One oneness,” the body of oneness. ... The whole universe is considered as one, the true [[Ik Onkar|Ekankar]]." —[[Julian Johnson]], ''The Path of the Masters'', 1985 pagination, pages 221–222. According to the Eckankar glossary, the term ''Eckankar'' means ''Co-Worker with God''.{{cite web|url=http://www.eckankar.com/glossary.html#eck|title=A Glossary of Eckankar Terms|website=www.eckankar.com|accessdate=16 March 2018}} ECK is another word for the Holy Spirit, also known as the Audible Life Current, Life Force, or Light and Sound of God.{{rp|55}} Eckankar's headquarters were originally in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], Nevada. Under the leadership of [[Darwin Gross]], the organization was moved to [[Menlo Park, California|Menlo Park]], California in 1975. In 1986, Harold Klemp moved the base of operations to [[Minneapolis, Minnesota|Minneapolis]], Minnesota."'Soul Travelers' Move", ''[[San Jose Mercury News]]'', 24 August 1986. The leader of Eckankar is known as 'the Living ECK Master'. Some leaders, Twitchell and Klemp, for example, also hold the title "Mahanta" which refers to the inner aspect of the teacher.[http://www.shabdkosh.com/translate/%E0%A4%AE%E0%A4%B9%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%A8%E0%A4%A4%E0%A4%BE/%E0%A4%AE%E0%A4%B9%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%A8%E0%A4%A4%E0%A4%BE-meaning-in-English-Hindi Etymology][[Mahanta (disambiguation)]] The leader functions as both an inner and outer guide for each member's individual spiritual progress. Twitchell (spiritual name: Peddar Zaskq) was the movement's spiritual leader until his death in late 1971. Gross (spiritual name: Dap Ren) succeeded him until October 22, 1981, when Klemp (spiritual name: Wah Z, pronounced Wah Zee) became the spiritual leader. Some scholars believe that Eckankar draws in part from the [[Sikhism|Sikh]] and [[Hinduism|Hindu]] religions,{{cite book|year=2001|title=The A to Z of New Religious Movements|location=Oxford, UK|publisher=Scarecrow Press|page=298|author=George D. Chryssides|quote=Eminating from the Radhosoami Satsang (q.v.) background, which is a synthesis of Hinduism and Sikhism (qq.v.), Eckankar teaches a form of surat sabda yoga...}} and the [[Sant Mat]] movement.Melton, J. Gordon (2003). Encyclopedia of American Religions (Seventh edition). Farmington Hills, Michigan: The Gale Group, Inc. {{ISBN|0-7876-6384-0}}. p. 1056. ==Beliefs== One of the basic tenets is that Soul (the true self) may be experienced separate from the physical body and in full consciousness travel freely in other planes of reality. Eckankar emphasizes personal spiritual experiences as the most natural way back to God.[http://www.eckankar.org/SEW/ Eckankar: Spiritual Exercise of the Week]. eckankar.org These are attained via Soul Travel shifting the awareness from the body to the inner planes of existence.Klemp, Harold. ''A Cosmic Sea of Words, The ECKANKAR Lexicon''. Minneapolis: Eckankar, 2009. {{ISBN|978-1-57043-286-6}}{{rp|187}} Certain [[mantra]]s or chants are used to facilitate spiritual growth. One important spiritual exercise of Eckankar is the singing or chanting of ''Hu'', and is viewed in Eckankar as a "love song to God". It is pronounced like the English word "hue" (or "hyoo") in a long, drawn-out breath and is sung for about half an hour. ECKists sing it alone or in groups.{{rp|59}} ECKists believe that singing Hu draws one closer in state of consciousness to the Divine Being and that it can expand awareness, help one experience divine love, heal broken hearts, offer solace in times of grief, and bring peace and calm.[http://www.eckankar.org/hu.html HU]. eckankar.org ECKists believe this practice allows the student to step back from the overwhelming input of the physical senses and emotions and regain Soul's spiritually higher viewpoint.{{rp|59}} Dreams are regarded as important teaching tools, and members often keep [[dream journal]]s to facilitate study.[http://www.eckankar.org/dream.html Dreams: A Source of Inner Truth]. eckankar.org According to followers of Eckankar, dream travel often serves as the gateway to Soul Travel[http://www.eckankar.org/soultravel.html Soul Travel]. eckankar.org or the shifting of one's consciousness to ever-higher states of being. Eckankar teaches that "spiritual liberation" in one's lifetime is available to all and that it is possible to achieve Self-Realization (the realization of oneself as Soul) and God-Realization (the realization of oneself as a spark of God) in one's lifetime. The membership card for Eckankar states: "The aim and purpose of Eckankar has always been to take Soul by Its own path back to Its divine source." The final spiritual goal of all ECKists is to become conscious "Co-workers" with God.{{rp|59}}''Shariyat-Ki-Sugmad'', Books One and Two, 65 The ''Shariyat-Ki-Sugmad'', which means "Way of the Eternal", is the holy scripture of Eckankar.Klemp, Harold, 1998, Cosmic Sea of Words: The Eckankar Lexicon. Eckankar, Minneapolis. It comprises two books that tell of spiritual meaning and purpose as written by the Mahanta.{{rp|59}} There are also a series of [[Satsang]] writings, that are available with yearly membership in Eckankar. There are Satsang classes available to study discourses with others, as well as individually.{{rp|177}} Some of the key beliefs taught in the ''Shariyat-Ki-Sugmad'' include Soul Travel, [[karma]], [[reincarnation]], love, Light and Sound, and many other spiritual topics. ECKists believe Sugmad is the endless source from which all forms were created, and that the ECK, the Sound Current, flows out of Sugmad and into lower dimensions.{{rp|59, 187, 194}} Primary to the teaching is the belief that one may experience the perspective of soul beyond the limits of the body. Also, the concepts of [[karma]] and [[reincarnation]] help to explain situations in life as the playing out of past causes.{{rp|186–187}} Primary to the teaching, derived solidly from third party sources as explained above, is the belief that one may experience the perspective of soul beyond the limits of the body. Also, the concepts of [[karma]] and [[reincarnation]] help to explain situations in life as the playing out of past causes.{{rp|186–187}} The beliefs that individuals are responsible for their own destiny and that their decisions determine their future are important concepts to Eckankar. Eckankar students meet in open public services and classes to discuss personal experiences, topics, books and discourses.{{rp|59}} ==Worship== Eckankar emphasizes personal spiritual experiences as the most natural way back to God. These are attained via the Spiritual Exercises of ECK. Eckankar offers a Spiritual Exercise of the Week[http://www.eckankar.org/spex.html] Spiritual Exercise of the Week. eckankar.org on its website. An ECK Light and Sound service generally includes a HU Song and contemplation, a talk or panel discussion from members of the Eckankar Clergy, and often includes creative arts and group discussion. Eckankar hosts a Worldwide Seminar in October and a Springtime Seminar every year. Eckankar also hosts annual seminars in countries around the world. ECK seminars include speakers, creative arts, workshops, discussion groups and other activities.[http://www.eckankar.org/Seminars/index.html Seminars]. eckankar.org ==Current status== The Eckankar "EK" symbol appears on the list of ''Available Emblems of Belief for Placement on Government Headstones and Markers'' by the [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cem.va.gov/hmm/emblems.asp|title=Available Emblems of Belief for Placement on Government Headstones and Markers - National Cemetery Administration|first=National Cemetery|last=Administration|website=www.cem.va.gov|accessdate=16 March 2018}} Sources estimate that there were around 50,000 followers in the 1990s.{{cite web|url=http://www.religionfacts.com/eckankar|title=Eckankar|website=Religion Facts|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150521015912/http://www.religionfacts.com/eckankar|archivedate=2015-05-21|quote="The Eckankar articles in the Encyclopedia Britannica and the Encyclopedia of American Religions (both by J. Gordon Melton) estimated total membership at 50,000 in the late 1990s."}} === ‌Iran === In February 2018, [[Iran]]ian agencies reported the execution of an Eckankar member for "establishing fake institution". [[Karim Zargar]], the former Iran TV's channel one broadcast manager, general manager of [[IRIB]]'s international section, head of the Faculty of Radio and Television, and owner and managing director of Film Reports magazine (Gozaresh-e-Film), was hanged at [[Rajayi-shahr Prison|Rajai Shahr Prison]]. [[Marjan Davari]], Mr. Zargar's former spouse, is also kept in prison and is sentenced to death for being a member of Eckankar.{{Cite web|url=http://www.insideofiran.org/en/index.php/2016-08-19-08-12-02/2016-09-21-15-25-58/3497-iran-executions-karim-zargar-the-head-of-a-spiritual-institution-was-hanged|title=Iran Executions: Karim Zargar, the Head of a Spiritual Institution, Was Hanged|last=user4|website=www.insideofiran.org|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-02-27}}{{Cite news|url=http://iran-hrm.com/index.php/2018/02/15/holder-ph-d-strasburg-university-law-degree-tehran-university-hanged-rajaie-shahr-prison-amidst-media-silence/|title=Karim Zargar Holder of Ph.D. from Strasburg University hanged in Iran|date=2018-02-15|work=Iran HRM|access-date=2018-02-27|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.iranhumanrights.org/2016/09/marjan-davari/|title=Translator in Prison for One Year Without Knowing Charges; Her Lawyer Denied Access to Case File – Center for Human Rights in Iran|website=www.iranhumanrights.org|access-date=2018-02-27}} Ms. Davari's family has stated in the media and online that she is merely a researcher and a translator and is not a follower of Eckankar.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/page.masihalinejad/videos/10154788020137740/|title=Masih Alinejad|website=www.facebook.com|accessdate=16 March 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/FreeMarjan|title=Amnesty International : Stop Execution of Marjan Davari #FreeMarjan|last=|first=|date=|website=Change.org|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-16}} ==Ceremonies and rites== There are few personal requirements to be an ECKist; however, certain spiritual practices are recommended. Chief among these is daily practice of the "Spiritual Exercises of ECK" for 15–20 minutes.{{rp|189}} The most basic ECK spiritual exercise is singing the word ''Hu''. A wide variety of spiritual exercises are offered, and members are encouraged to create their own. There are no dietary requirements, taboos, or enforced ascetic practices. Eckankar does not require potential members to leave their current faith to join. There are a number of ceremonies an ECKist can experience as part of the teaching, including a Consecration ceremony for initiating the young and infants, a Rite of Passage into adulthood (around age 13), a Wedding ceremony, and a Memorial service.{{rp|186}} ECKists celebrate a spiritual new year on October 22. There is no organizational celebration of personal anniversaries, such as birthdays of the leaders.{{Cite web|url=https://www.eckankar.org/abouteckankar.pdf|title=About Eckankar: An Overview of Eckankar and It's Teachings (PDF)|last=|first=|date=2003|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ==ECK Masters== ECKists believe contact with Divine Spirit, which they call the ''ECK'', can be made via the spiritual exercises of ECK and the guidance of the living ECK Master. It is held that the ECK Masters are here to serve all life irrespective of religious belief. The main Eckankar website includes a list of Masters.[http://www.eckankar.org/Masters/index.html Official Eckankar Masters List]. eckankar.org Writing in ''Introduction to New and Alternative Religions in America'', David Christopher Lane observes: {{Quote|This lineage, known as the Vairagi[[Vairagya]] masters in Eckankar, allegedly traces its genealogy back through some 970 Living Eck Masters to Rama, an avatar of Vishnu in Hinduism. In other versions, the teachings go even further back to Gakko, a spiritual essence that traveled from the city of Retz on the planet Venus to Earth six million years ago.{{cite book |title =''Eckankar'' in Introduction to New and Alternative Religions in America (ed Eugene V. Gallagher and W. Michael Ashcraft)Volume 3: Metaphysical, New Age, and Neopagan Movements|pages = 115|first = David Christopher|last = Lane| year = 2006|publisher = Greeenwood Press}}}} ==See also== * [[Ancient Teachings of the Masters]] * [[Contemporary Sant Mat movement]] * [[Gopal Das (disambiguation)]] * [[Ik Onkar]] * [[Mahanta (disambiguation)]] * [[Marjan Davari]] * [[Satsang]] * [[Vairag]] * [[Vairagya]] * [[Vairagya Shatakam]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * Dogra, Ramesh Chander & Gobind Singh Mansukhani, ''Encyclopaedia of Sikh Religion and Culture'', Vikas, 1995. {{ISBN|978-0706994995}}. * Ellwood, Robert S. and Partin, Harry B. (1988), Religious and Spiritual Groups in Modern America, Second Edition, Prentice Hall, New Jersey. * Lane, David Christopher, ''The Making of a Spiritual Movement: The Untold Story of Paul Twitchell and Eckankar'', Del Mar, California: Del Mar Press, 1990. {{ISBN|0-9611124-0-9}} * Marman, Doug (2007) ''The Whole Truth: The Spiritual Legacy of Paul Twitchell'', Ridgefield, Washington: Spiritual Dialogues Project. {{ISBN|978-0-9793260-0-4}} * Woods, Len, (2008), Handbook of World Religions, Barbour Publishing, Ohio. ==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{official}} {{Religion topics}} [[Category:1965 establishments in Nevada]] [[Category:Meditation]] [[Category:Monotheistic religions]] [[Category:New religious movements]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1965]] [[Category:Shabda]]

{{Infobox political party | name = Ecology Democracy Party | logo = MN EDP logo.png | colorcode = {{Ecology Democracy Party/meta/color}} | chairman = Andrew Schuler | founder = [[Ken Pentel]] | leader1_title = Governor | leader1_name = | leader2_title = Senate leader | leader2_name = | leader3_title = House leader | leader3_name = | founded = {{start date|2010}} | headquarters = | ideology = [[Deep ecology]]
[[Green politics]] | colors = [[Green]] and [[blue]] | seats1_title = [[Minnesota Senate|Senate]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|0|67|hex={{Ecology Democracy Party/meta/color}}}} | seats2_title = [[Minnesota House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] | seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|134|hex={{Ecology Democracy Party/meta/color}}}} | seats3_title = [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]] | seats3 = {{Composition bar|0|2|hex={{Ecology Democracy Party/meta/color}}}} | seats4_title = [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]] | seats4 = {{Composition bar|0|8|hex={{Ecology Democracy Party/meta/color}}}} | website = {{URL|http://www.ecologydemocracyparty.org/}} | state = Minnesota }} The '''Ecology Democracy Party''' is a [[Deep ecology|deep ecological]] [[political party]] in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Minnesota]]. Founded in 2010 by [[Ken Pentel]], the party advocates a "shift from a human-centered to an ecological view of the world."[http://www.ecologydemocracynetwork.org/ Ecology Democracy Network] Pentel was the [[Green Party of Minnesota]] candidate for [[Governor of Minnesota]] in 1998, 2002, and 2006. He has said his motivation for founding a new party was "the lack of discipline and low expectations among the movements and organizations I have worked with."{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} ==Ideology== The purpose of the Ecology Democracy Party is to restore a [[sustainable]] relationship with the Earth through education and [[grassroots]] organizing. The party attempts to offer guidance for necessary structural changes in the economy, the way we vote, and who influences our government. It attempts to accomplish these structural changes through three mandates: # The establishment of an [[ecology]]-based economy. # The implementation of [[proportional representation]] in the [[Minnesota House of Representatives]]. # The removal of private money and corporate interference from the people's government. The party advocates [[ecology]], [[campaign finance reform]], [[proportional representation]], ending [[corporate personhood]], [[holism]], public funding of elections and establishing a tax-refundable Minnesota currency with zero interest.[http://woowooteacup.wordpress.com/2010/07/09/ken-pentel-the-ecology-democracy-party/ Ken Pentel & the Ecology Democracy Party] ==Elections== Ken Pentel ran for Governor of Minnesota in 2010 and received 6,180 votes, or 0.29%.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} In 2012 the party endorsed write-in candidate Andrew Schuler for U.S. Senate and ran Anthony Hilton for the State House, district 59B. Hilton received 1,423 votes, or 8.05%. It also ran Danene Provencher for Mound City Council, who received 26% of the vote. In 2015 Schuler was endorsed as a candidate for Golden Valley City Council. He received 8.32% of the vote.http://www.hennepin.us/residents/elections/election-results ==See also== * [[Politics of Minnesota]] * [[List of political parties in Minnesota]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.ecologydemocracyparty.org/ Ecology Democracy Party] * [http://www.ecologydemocracynetwork.org/ Ecology Democracy Network] {{Minnesota political parties}} {{United States state and local political parties}} [[Category:Deep ecology]] [[Category:Green political parties in the United States]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2008]] [[Category:Political parties in Minnesota]]

{{Infobox person | name = Emanuel Bronner | image = Emanuel Bronner.jpg | alt = A picture of a blind man wearing dark glasses and a white coat grinning while holding a bottle of soap. Steam, presumably [[dry ice]], billows from below, giving the photograph a science-fiction feel. | caption = | birth_name = Emanuel Theodor Heilbronner | birth_date = {{Birth date|1908|02|01}} | birth_place = [[Heilbronn]], [[German Empire]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1997|03|07|1908|02|01}} | death_place = [[California]] | nationality = German-American | other_names = | occupation = Soap maker, entrepreneur, philosopher | years_active = | known_for = [[Dr. Bronner's Magic Soaps]] | notable_works = }} '''Emanuel Theodore Bronner''' (born {{Audio|Emanuel Heilbronner.ogg|'''Emanuel Heilbronner'''}},<ref name="journal-sentinel" /> February 1, 1908 – March 7, 1997) was the maker of '''[[Dr. Bronner's Magic Soaps]]'''.<ref>{{cite book |author=Bryony Gomez Palacio, Armin Vit |title=Graphic Design Referenced: A Visual Guide to the Language, Applications, and History of Graphic Design |page=311 |publisher=Rockport Publishers |year=2011 |isbn=978-1592537426}}</ref> He used product labels to promote his moral and religious ideas, including a belief in the goodness and unity of humanity.
== History == [[File:BronnerNaturalizationCertificatePhoto.jpg|thumb|left|Bronner in 1936]] [[File:BronnerNaturalizationCertificate.jpg|thumb|right|Bronner's 1936 naturalization certificate making him a U.S. citizen]] Bronner was born in [[Heilbronn]], [[Germany]], to the Heilbronner family of soap makers.<ref name="db" /> He emigrated to the [[United States]] in 1929, dropping "Heil" from his name because of its associations with [[Nazism]].<ref name=":0">Lubinski, Christina and Marvin Menniken. [http://www.immigrantentrepreneurship.org/entry.php?rec=134 "Emanuel Bronner."] In ''Immigrant Entrepreneurship: German-American Business Biographies, 1720 to the Present'', vol. 5, edited by R. Daniel Wadhwani. German Historical Institute. Last modified October 25, 2013.</ref> He became a naturalized citizen of the United States in 1936.<ref name=":0" /> As the family was [[Jewish]], he pleaded with his parents to emigrate with him for fear of the then-ascendant [[Nazism|Nazi Party]], but they refused. His last contact with his parents was in the form of a [[Censorship|censored]] [[postcard]] saying, "You were right. —Your loving father."<ref name="sd" /> His parents died in [[the Holocaust]].
== Career == He started his business making products by hand, such as [[castile soap]], in his home. The product labels are crowded with statements of Bronner's philosophy, which he called "All-One-God-Faith" and the "Moral ABC",<ref>{{Cite news | last = Foster | first = Tom | title = The Undiluted Genius of Dr. Bronner's | work = Inc.com | accessdate = 2014-10-24 | date = 2012-04-03 | url = http://www.inc.com/magazine/201204/tom-foster/the-undiluted-genius-of-dr-bronners.html }}</ref> both of which he included on the label of every soap bottle he produced.<ref>Ben Ehrlich, ''Dr. Bronner's Soapy History'', The [Jewish] Forward, June 29, 2007, page 2.</ref> Many of Bronner's references came from [[Judaism|Jewish]] and [[Christianity|Christian]] sources, such as the [[Shema]] and the [[Beatitudes]]; others from writers such as [[Rudyard Kipling]] and [[Thomas Paine]]. On his labels he referred to the Jewish sage [[Hillel the Elder]] as "Rabbi Hillel" and to [[Jesus Christ]] as "Rabbi Jesus."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.drbronner.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Moral-ABC-2015-Edition.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-09-14 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161219201502/https://www.drbronner.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Moral-ABC-2015-Edition.pdf |archivedate=December 19, 2016 |df= }} "The Moral ABC [Parts] I & II" by Dr. Emmanuel Bronner. Page 23: "Rabbi Hillel taught Jesus to unite the whole human race in our Eternal Father’s great, All-One-God-Faith." Page 36: "A Human being must teach friend & Enemy the Moral ABC uniting all mankind free or that being is not yet human! Rabbi Jesus’ full truth No. 1." Page 39: "To stay free: Small minds discuss people. Average minds discuss events. Great minds teach Rabbi Hillel’s Moral ABC."</ref> The labels became famous for their idiosyncratic style, including hyphens to join long strings of words and the liberal use of [[exclamation mark]]s.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Philpott | first = Tom | title = Why Did Top Scientific Journals Reject This Dr. Bronner's Ad? | work = [[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] | accessdate = 2014-10-24 | date = 2014-10-20 | url = https://www.motherjones.com/tom-philpott/2014/10/read-dr-bronners-gmo-ad-thats-too-hot-nature-and-science }}</ref>
In 1946, while promoting his "Moral ABC" at the [[University of Chicago]], Bronner was arrested for speaking without a permit, despite the fact he was invited to the campus to lecture by a local student group, and then committed to the [[Elgin Mental Health Center]], a mental hospital in [[Elgin, Illinois]], from which he escaped after [[Electroconvulsive therapy|shock treatments]].<ref name="journal-sentinel" /> Bronner believed those shock treatments brought about his eventual blindness.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Sherman |first=Pat |date=February 2007 |title=In the Spirit of Soap: Dr. Bronner's Magic Soaps may be Escondido's cleanest (and perhaps oddest) success story |url=http://www.sandiegomagazine.com/San-Diego-Magazine/February-2007/In-the-Spirit-of-Soap/ |journal=San Diego Magazine |publisher=CurtCo/SDM |volume=59 |issue=4 |pages=107 |access-date=15 September 2015}}</ref>
After moving his family several times, he settled in [[Escondido, California]], where eventually his soap-making operation grew into a small factory. At his death in 1997, it produced more than a million bottles of soap and other products per year, but was still not mechanized.<ref name="ts" /> The firm has been the subject of many published articles and has supported many charitable causes.<ref name="ts" />
==Legacy== After Bronner's death, his family has continued to run the business. His grandson [[David Bronner (Dr. Bronner's)|David Bronner]] is currently CEO.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Harkinson | first = Josh | title = How Dr. Bronner's Soap Turned Activism Into Good Clean Fun | work = Mother Jones | accessdate = 2014-10-24 | date = 2014-05-24 | url = https://www.motherjones.com/environment/2014/02/dr-bronners-magic-soap-david-bronner-gmo-hemp }}</ref><ref name="Applying Fair Trade Principles To A Manufacturing Supply Chain (presentation by Gero Leson, Dr. Bronner's Magic Soaps Director of Special Operations)">{{cite web|last1=Leson|first1=Gero|title=Applying Fair Trade Principles To A Manufacturing Supply Chain (presentation by Gero Leson, Dr. Bronner's Magic Soaps Director of Special Operations)|url=http://wfto.com/sites/default/files/REDUCED%20VERSION%20-%20Applying%20Fair%20Trade%20Principles%20To%20A%20Manufacturing....pdf|publisher=[[World Fair Trade Organization]]|accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref> The family has said the labels he wrote will not change except when required by government regulations.<ref name="db" />
His life was the subject of a 2007 [[documentary film]], ''Dr. Bronner's Magic Soapbox'', which premiered on the [[Sundance TV]] channel, on 3 July 2007.<ref name="NYTmoviereview" /><ref>{{Cite news | issue = November/December | last = McClelland | first = Mac | title = Dr. Bronner's Magic Soapbox | work = Mother Jones | accessdate = 2014-10-24 | date = 2007 | url = https://www.motherjones.com/media/2007/10/dr-bronners-magic-soapbox }}</ref><ref>Ben Ehrlich, ''Dr. Bronner's Soapy History'', The [Jewish] Forward, June 29, 2007, page 2.</ref>
The [[Sea Shepherd Conservation Society]] has a ship, the {{MV|Emanuel Bronner}}, donated by the soap company.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Introducing the latest addition to the Sea Shepherd fleet, the M/V Emanuel Bronner | work = Sea Shepherd | accessdate = 2017-11-13 | date = June 2, 2017 | url = https://www.seashepherdglobal.org/latest-news/newest-addition-to-the-sea-shepherd-fleet-generous/ }}</ref>
== References ==

Four to five people, not working fast, pack them with no machines |date=January 2001 | accessdate = 2007-10-23 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20010508090128/http://www.thesunmagazine.org/bronner.html |archivedate = 2001-05-08}} </ref>

The '''Escalation Hypothesis''' is a theory put forward by [[Geerat J. Vermeij]]. It states that organisms are in constant conflict with one another and therefore devote lots of resources to thwarting the adaptations [[evolution]] brings to all competing organisms as time advances. This is in contrast to adaptations evolution may bring that are unrelated to competition with other organisms such as adapting to ecological niches based upon other factors such as geology and climate.
Vermeij's extensive work with the characteristics of marine [[gastropod]] fossils informed his development of thoughts on escalation. One prediction of the Escalation Hypothesis is that individual species having fewer adaptations that enable them to compete with other life forms are more likely to survive a mass [[extinction event]] such as one of [[extinction event#Major extinction events|The Big Five]]. This is because there is more flexibility to fit into new ecological niches that arduous adaptations such as heavy shells or energy consuming venom production would hinder.
==External links== *[http://palaios.sepmonline.org/cgi/content/extract/18/2/83 The Escalation Hypothesis: One Long Argument]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2012}} '''Eugene Kamenka''' (4 March 1928 – 19 January 1994) was an Australian political philosopher and Marxist scholar.
==Biography== Kamenka was born in [[Cologne]] in 1928 and taken to [[Australia]] in 1937. He was educated at the [[Sydney Technical High School]], and after interrupting his studies went to Jerusalem where he married his first wife Miriam Mizrachi and with her encouragement he returned to [[Sydney University]] to complete his degree and begin work on his later published thesis "The Ethical Foundations of [[Marxism]]" for the Australian national university, publ 1962. Professor [[John Anderson (philosopher)|John Anderson]] of Sydney University was a key influence in his early career.
Kamenka lectured in philosophy at the [[University of Singapore]] where he met his second wife, [[Alice Tay]] and lectured and researched in [[Europe]], [[North America]] and most countries in [[Asia]]; he was a Professor and the Head of the History of Ideas Unit at the Institute of Advanced Studies of the Australian National University, and lived in [[Canberra]]. Together with his second wife, a professor of jurisprudence at Sydney University and scholar of comparative and Asian legal systems, he authored several works in philosophy of law and comparative law.<ref>{{cite news|title=Eugene Kamenka, 65, An Australian Thinker|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/26/obituaries/eugene-kamenka-65-an-australian-thinker.html |newspaper=The New York Times|date=26 January 1994|access-date=5 January 2017}}</ref>
He died in Canberra.
==Works== *''Marxism and Ethics'' (1969) *''A World in Revolution?'' (1970) *''The Philosophy of [[Ludwig Feuerbach]]'' (1970) *''Nationalism: The Nature and Evolution of an Idea'' (1976) *''The Portable Karl Marx'' (1983) *''Bureaucracy'' (1989)

{{Infobox philosopher | name = Jean-Luc Marion | image = JLMarion.jpg | region = [[Western philosophy]] | era = [[20th-century philosophy|20th-]]/[[21st-century philosophy]] | school = [[Continental Philosophy]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1946|7|3|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Meudon]], [[Hauts-de-Seine]] | alma_mater = [[École Normale Supérieure]] | school_tradition = [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|Phenomenology]] | main_interests = [[Philosophical theology]], [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|Phenomenology]], [[Descartes]] | influences = {{hlist | [[Augustine]] | [[Louis Althusser|Althusser]] | [[Hans Urs von Balthasar|Balthasar]] | [[Bernard of Clairveaux]] | [[Henri Bergson|Bergson]] | [[:fr:Claude Bruaire|Bruaire]] | [[Jean Daniélou|Daniélou]] | [[Jacques Derrida|Derrida]] | [[René Descartes|Descartes]] | [[Martin Heidegger|Heidegger]] | [[Michel Henry|Henry]] |[[Edmund Husserl|Husserl]] | [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]] | [[Emmanuel Lévinas|Lévinas]] | [[Pseudo-Dionysus|Pseudo-Denys]]}} | influenced = {{hlist | [[:fr:Emmanuel Falque|Falque]]}} | notable_ideas = "As much [[Phenomenological reduction|reduction]], as much givenness," saturated phenomenon, the [[intentionality]] of love }} {{Historical Christian theology}}
'''Jean-Luc Marion''' (born 3 July 1946) is a French [[philosophy|philosopher]] and [[Roman Catholic]] [[theology|theologian]]. Marion is a former student of [[Jacques Derrida]] whose work is informed by [[patristics|patristic]] and [[mystical theology]], [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenology]], and [[modern philosophy]].<ref name="Horner.2C_Robyn_2005">Horner 2005.</ref> Much of his academic work has dealt with [[Descartes]] and phenomenologists like [[Martin Heidegger]] and [[Edmund Husserl]], but also religion. ''God Without Being'', for example, is concerned predominantly with an analysis of [[idolatry]], a theme strongly linked in Marion's work with [[love]] and the [[gift]], which is a concept also explored at length by Derrida.
==Biography==
===Early years=== Marion was born in [[Meudon]], [[Hauts-de-Seine]], on 3 July 1946. He studied at the University of Nanterre (now the [[University Paris X|University Paris Ouest Nanterre La Défense]]) and the [[University of Paris IV: Paris-Sorbonne|Sorbonne]] and then did graduate work in philosophy from the [[École Normale Supérieure]] in Paris, where he was taught by [[Jacques Derrida]], [[Louis Althusser]] and [[Gilles Deleuze]].<ref name="Horner_05_p3">Horner 2005, p. 3.</ref> At the same time, Marion's deep interest in theology was privately cultivated under the personal influence of theologians such as [[Louis Bouyer]], [[Jean Daniélou]], [[Henri de Lubac]], and [[Hans Urs von Balthasar]]. From 1972 to 1980 he studied for his doctorate and worked as an assistant lecturer at the Sorbonne. After receiving his doctorate in 1980, he began teaching at the [[University of Poitiers]].<ref name="Horner_05_p3"/>
===Career=== From there he moved to become the Director of Philosophy at the [[University Paris X|University Paris X – Nanterre]], and in 1991 also took up the role of ''professeur invité'' at the Institut Catholique de Paris.<ref>Horner 2005, p. 5.</ref> In 1996 he became Director of Philosophy at the University of Paris IV ([[University of Paris IV: Paris-Sorbonne|Sorbonne]]), where he still teaches.
Marion became a visiting professor at the [[University of Chicago Divinity School]] in 1994. He was then appointed the John Nuveen Professor of the Philosophy of Religion and Theology there in 2004, a position he held until 2010.<ref name="Horner, Robyn 2005">Horner, Robyn. Jean-Luc Marion: a Theo-Logical Introduction. Burlington: Ashgate, 2005.</ref> That year, he was appointed the Andrew Thomas Greeley and Grace McNichols Greeley Professor of Catholic Studies at the Divinity School, a position that had been vacated by the retirement of theologian [[David Tracy]].<ref>University of Chicago 2010.</ref>
On 6 November 2008, Marion was elected as an ''immortel'' by the [[Académie française]]. Marion now occupies [[List of members of the Académie française#Seat 4|seat 4]] an office previously held by Cardinal [[Jean-Marie Lustiger|Lustiger]].<ref name="AF">Académie française, 2008.</ref><ref name="AFPGN">L’Agence France-Presse 2008.</ref>
His awards include:<ref name="AF"/><ref name="divbio">University of Chicago Divinity School 2015.</ref> * the [[Karl Jaspers]] Prize of the city and University of Heidelberg (2008). * the ''Grand Prix de philosophie de l'Académie française'' (1992), for his entire ''oeuvre'' * the ''Prix Charles Lambert de l'Académie des sciences morales et politiques'' (1977)
==Philosophy== Marion's [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenological]] work is set out in three volumes which together form a [[triptych]]<ref>Marion 2002a, p.ix.</ref> or [[trilogy]].<ref>Marion 2002b, p.ix.</ref> ''Réduction et donation: Etudes sur Husserl, Heidegger et la phénoménologie'' (1989) is an historical study of the phenomenological method followed by [[Edmund Husserl|Husserl]] and [[Martin Heidegger|Heidegger]], with a view towards suggesting future directions for phenomenological research. The unexpected reaction that ''Réduction et donation'' provoked called for clarification and full development. This was addressed in ''Étant donné: Essai d'une phénoménologie de la donation'' (1997), a more conceptual work investigating phenomenological givenness, the saturated phenomenon and the gifted—a rethinking of the subject. ''Du surcroît'' (2001) provides an in-depth description of saturated phenomena.<ref>Marion 2002a, pp.ix-x.</ref>
===Givenness=== Marion claims that he has attempted to "radically reduce the whole phenomenological project beginning with the primacy in it of givenness".<ref>Marion 2002b, p.xxi.</ref> What he describes as his one and only theme is the givenness that is required before phenomena can show themselves in consciousness—"what ''shows itself'' first ''gives itself''.<ref>Marion 2002a, p.5.</ref> This is based on the argument that any and all attempts to lead phenomena back to immanence in consciousness, that is, to exercise the phenomenological reduction, necessarily results in showing that givenness is the "sole horizon of phenomena"<ref>Robyn Horner, translator, in Marion 2002b, p.ix.</ref>
Marion radicalizes this argument in the formulation, "As much reduction, as much givenness",<ref>Marion 1998, p.203; Marion 2002a, p.16; Marion 2002b, p.17-19; see Marion 2002b, p.x, note 4 for translator's note.</ref> and offers this as a new first principle of [[phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenology]], building on and challenging prior formulae of [[Husserl]] and [[Heidegger]].<ref>Marion 1998, p.203; Marion 2002a, p.14-19; Marion 2002b, p.16-19.</ref> The formulation common to both, Marion argues, "So much appearance, so much Being", adopted from [[Johann Friedrich Herbart]],<ref>Marion 2002a, p.329, note 4.</ref> erroneously elevates ''appearing'' to the status of the "sole face of Being". In doing so, it leaves appearing itself undetermined, not subject to the [[Eidetic reduction|reduction]], and thus in a "typically metaphysical situation".<ref>Marion 2002a, p.11.</ref>
The Husserlian formulation, "To the things themselves!", is criticized on the basis that the things in question would remain what they are even without appearing to a subject—again circumventing the reduction or even without becoming phenomena. Appearing becomes merely a mode of access to objects, rendering the formulation inadequate as a first principle of phenomenology.<ref>Marion 2002a, p.12.</ref> A third formulation, Husserl's "Principle of all Principles", states "that ''every primordial dator [[Phenomenology (philosophy)#Intuition|Intuition]] is a source of authority (Rechtsquelle) for knowledge'', that ''whatever presents itself in {{'}}intuition{{'}}...is simply to be accepted as it gives itself out to be'', though ''only within the limits in which it then presents itself''."<ref>Husserl 1969, p.92.</ref> Marion argues that while the Principle of all Principles places givenness as phenomenality's criterion and achievement, givenness still remains uninterrogated.<ref name="2002b17">Marion 2002b, p.17.</ref> Whereas it admits limits to intuition ("as it gives itself..., though only within the limits in which it presents itself"), "givenness alone is absolute, free and without condition"<ref>{{cite book | last = Husserl | first = Edmund | authorlink = Edmund_Husserl | title = Die Idee der Phänomenologie, Husserliania II | pages = 61 and 50 respectively}} Cited in Marion 1998, p.33 and Marion 2002b p.17-18.</ref>
Givenness then is not reducible except to itself, and so is freed from the limits of any other authority, including intuition; a reduced given is either given or not given. "As much reduction, as much givenness" states that givenness is what the reduction accomplishes, and any reduced given is reduced to givenness.<ref>Marion 2002a, p.17.</ref> The more a phenomenon is reduced, the more it is given. Marion calls the formulation the last principle, equal to the first, that of the appearing itself.<ref>Marion 2002b, p.26.</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |+ Phenomenological reductions of Husserl, Heidegger and Marion<ref>Marion 1998, pp.204-205.</ref> !   !! To whom are the things in question led back by the reduction? !! What is given by the reduction? !! How are the things in question given; what is the horizon? !! How far does the reduction go, what is excluded? |- ! scope="row" | First reduction{{spaced ndash}}transcendental ([[Edmund Husserl|Husserl]]) | The intentional and constituting ''I'' || Constituted objects || Through regional [[Ontology|ontologies]]. Through formal ontology, regional ontologies fall within the horizon of objectivity || Excludes everything that does not let itself be led back to objectivity |- ! scope="row" | Second reduction{{spaced ndash}}existential ([[Martin Heidegger|Heidegger]]) | ''Dasein'': an intentionality broadened to Being-in-the-world and led back to its transcendence of beings through anxiety || The different ways of Being; the "phenomenon of Being" || According to Being as the original and ultimate phenomenon. According to the horizon of time || Excludes that which does not have to be, especially the preliminary conditions of the phenomenon of Being, e.g. [[Boredom#Philosophy|boredom]], the claim |- ! scope="row" | Third reduction{{spaced ndash}}to givenness (Marion) | The ''interloqué'': that which is called by the claim of the phenomenon<ref>Marion 1998, p.200-202.</ref> || The gift itself; the gift of rendering oneself to ''or'' of eluding the claim of the call || According to the horizon of the absolutely unconditional call and of the absolutely unconstrained response || Absence of conditions and determinations of the claim. Gives all that can call and be called |}
By describing the structures of phenomena from the basis of givenness, Marion claims to have succeeded in describing certain phenomena that previous metaphysical and phenomenological approaches either ignore or exclude—givens that show themselves but which a thinking that does not go back to the given is powerless to receive.<ref>Marion 2002a, pp.3-4.</ref> In all, three types of phenomena can be shown, according to the proportionality between what is given in [[Phenomenology (philosophy)#Intuition|intuition]] and what is [[Phenomenology (philosophy)#Intentionality|intended]]:
*Phenomena where little or nothing is given in intuition.<ref>Marion 2002a, pp.222, 308.</ref> Examples include the [[Nothing#Existentialists|Nothing]] and death,<ref>Marion 2002a, pp.53-59.</ref> mathematics and logic.<ref>Marion 2002a, pp.191-196.</ref> Marion claims that metaphysics, in particular [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]] (but also [[Husserl]]), privileges this type of phenomenon.<ref>Marion 2002a, pp.194, 226.</ref> *Phenomena where there is adequation between what is given in intuition and what is intended. This includes any [[Objectivity (science)|objective phenomena]].<ref>Marion 2002a, pp.222-225.</ref> *Phenomena where what is given in intuition fills or surpasses intentionality. These are named saturated phenomena.<ref>Marion 2002a, pp.196-221, 225-247 and Marion 2002b.</ref>
===The saturated phenomenon=== {{Technical|section|date=July 2012}} According to [[John D. Caputo]], Marion "is famous for the idea of what he calls the "saturated phenomenon," which is inspired by his study of Christian Neoplatonic mystical theologians....[The idea that] there are phenomena of such overwhelming givenness or overflowing fulfillment that the intentional acts aimed at these phenomena are overrun, flooded—or saturated."<ref>Caputo 2007 p. 164.</ref>
==="The Intentionality of Love"=== The fourth section of Marion's work ''Prolegomena to Charity'' is entitled "The Intentionality of Love" and primarily concerns [[intentionality]] and [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenology]]. Influenced by (and dedicated to) the French philosopher [[Emmanuel Levinas]], Marion explores the human idea of love and its lack of definition: "We live with love as if we knew what it was about. But as soon as we try to define it, or at least approach it with concepts, it draws away from us."<ref name="Marion, Jean-Luc 2002">Marion 2002c</ref> He begins by explaining the essence of consciousness and its "lived experiences." Paradoxically, the consciousness concerns itself with objects transcendent and exterior to itself, objects irreducible to consciousness, but can only comprehend its 'interpretation' of the object; the reality of the object arises from consciousness alone. Thus the problem with love is that to love another is to love one's own idea of another, or the "lived experiences" that arise in the consciousness from the "chance cause" of another: "I must, then, name this love ''my'' love, since it would not fascinate me as my idol if, first, it did not render to me, like an unseen mirror, the image of myself. Love, loved for itself, inevitably ends as self-love, in the phenomenological figure of self-idolatry."<ref name="Marion, Jean-Luc 2002"/> Marion believes intentionality is the solution to this problem, and explores the difference between the ''I'' who intentionally sees objects and the ''me'' who is intentionally seen by a counter-consciousness, another, whether the ''me'' likes it or not. Marion defines another by its invisibility; one can see objects through intentionality, but in the invisibility of the other, one '''is''' seen. Marion explains this invisibility using the [[pupil]]: "Even for a gaze aiming objectively, the pupil remains a living refutation of objectivity, an irremediable denial of the object; here for the first time, in the very midst of the visible, there is nothing to see, except an invisible and untargetable void...my gaze, for the first time, sees an invisible gaze that sees it."<ref name="Marion, Jean-Luc 2002"/> Love, then, when freed from intentionality, is the weight of this other's invisible gaze upon one's own, the cross of one's own gaze and the other's and the "unsubstitutability" of the other. Love is to "render oneself there in an unconditional surrender...no other gaze must respond to the ecstasy of ''this particular'' other exposed in his gaze." Perhaps in allusion to a theological argument, Marion concludes that this type of surrender "requires faith."<ref name="Marion, Jean-Luc 2002"/>

The '''Jerusalem Colophon''' is a [[Colophon (publishing)|colophon]] found in a number of [[Biblical manuscript#New Testament manuscripts|New Testament manuscripts]], including [[Codex Tischendorfianus III|Λ (039)]], [[Minuscule 20|20]], [[Minuscule 153|153]], [[Minuscule 157|157]], [[Minuscule 164|164]], [[Minuscule 215|215]], [[Minuscule 262|262]], [[Minuscule 300|300]], [[Minuscule 376|376]], [[Minuscule 428|428]], [[Minuscule 565|565]], [[Minuscule 566|566]], [[Minuscule 686|686]], [[Minuscule 718|718]], [[Minuscule 728|728]], [[Minuscule 748|748]], [[Minuscule 829 (Gregory-Aland)|829]], [[Minuscule 899 (Gregory-Aland)|899]], [[Minuscule 901 (Gregory-Aland)|901]], [[Minuscule 922 (Gregory-Aland)|922]], [[Minuscule 960 (Gregory-Aland)|980]], [[Minuscule 1032 (Gregory-Aland)|1032]], [[Minuscule 1071 (Gregory-Aland)|1071]], [[Minuscule 1118|1118]], [[Minuscule 1121|1121]], [[Minuscule 1124|1124]], [[Minuscule 1187 (Gregory-Aland)|1187]], [[Minuscule 1198|1198]], [[Minuscule 1355|1355]], [[Minuscule 1422|1422]], [[Minuscule 1521|1521]], [[Minuscule 1545|1545]], [[Minuscule 1555|1555]], [[Minuscule 1682|1682]], [[Minuscule 2145|2145]], and [[Minuscule 2245|2245]].<ref>Alfred Schmidtke, ''Neu Fragmente und Untersuchungen zu den judenchristlichen Evangelein'' (TU 37/1; Leipzig, Hinrichs, 1911, p. 3</ref> The full version of the colophon is εὐαγγέλιον κατὰ Ματθαῖον ἐγράφη καὶ ὰντεβλήθη ἐκ τῶν Ἱεροσολύμοις παλαιῶν ἀντιγράφων τῶν ἐν τῷ Ἁγίῳ Ὃρει ἀποκειμένων ἐν στίχοις {{overline|͵βφιδ}}. κεφφ. {{overline|τνε}}.<ref name = Gregory>{{Cite book | last = Gregory | first = Caspar René | authorlink = Caspar René Gregory | title = Textkritik des Neuen Testaments | publisher = J. C. Hinrichs | year = 1900 | location = Leipzig | volume = 1 | pages = 203–204 | url = https://archive.org/details/textkritikdesne00greggoog | isbn = }}</ref> – that the manuscript (in this case the "Gospel According to Matthew") was "copied and corrected from the ancient exemplars from [[Jerusalem in Christianity|Jerusalem]] preserved on the holy mountain" (according to the majority{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}} of scholars, it was [[Mount Athos]]) in 2514 verses and 355 chapters. Usually the colophon is abbreviated in subsequent mentions in the same manuscript. The texts of the manuscripts that share the colophon are not necessarily textually related (though a surprising number belong to Group Λ (039), 164, 262, and perhaps some of the many manuscripts Wisse does not classify). In many cases the colophon was copied down from document to document independent of the text. The majority of these manuscripts are representative of the [[Byzantine text-type]].
The meaning of the colophon was discussed by [[Kirsopp Lake]]. Lake holds that the "Holy Mountain" is [[Biblical Mount Sinai|Mount Sinai]].<ref>K. Lake, [https://archive.org/stream/journaltheologi02unkngoog#page/n462/mode/2up ''On the Italian Origin of Codex Bezae''], ''[[Journal of Theological Studies]]'', Vol. I, No. 3 (April, 1900), p. 445</ref>
According to [[Caspar René Gregory]] it would be possible that the manuscript Tischendorfianus III was written and corrected in Jerusalem.<ref>C. R. Gregory, [https://archive.org/stream/canonandtextnew00greguoft#page/n377/mode/2up "Canon and Text of the New Testament"] (1907), p. 360.</ref>

[[File:VEGISRAEL260.jpg|300px|thumbnail|Activists of 'Behemla' - an organization devoted to increasing awareness of [[cruelty to animals|animal cruelty]] among [[Haredim|ultra-orthodox Jews]] (World Farm Animals Day, 2013)]]
'''Jewish vegetarianism''' is the belief that following a [[Vegetarianism|vegetarian diet]] is demanded by the [[Torah]] or by other [[Jewish ethics|Jewish values]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.all-creatures.org/fact/fact-20080901-2.pdf|title=A Case for Jewish Vegetarianism|publisher=PETA}}</ref> While classical Jewish law neither requires nor prohibits the consumption of meat, Jewish vegetarians often cite Jewish principles regarding [[Jewish ethics#Treatment of animals|animal welfare]], [[Jewish ethics#Environmental ethics|environmental ethics]], moral character, and [[Jewish ethics#Health and self-respect|health]] as reasons for adopting a vegetarian or [[vegan]] diet.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://hazon.org/jewish-food-movement/food-choices/animal-welfare/|title=Animal Welfare - Hazon|work=Hazon|access-date=2018-03-26|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>Mary L. Zamore, ed. The Sacred Table: Creating a Jewish Food Ethic (New York, NY: CCAR Press, 2011).</ref>
==Ancient and Medieval Jewish Vegetarianism==
[[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] 1:29 states "And God said: Behold, I have given you every herb yielding seed which is upon the face of all the earth, and every tree that has seed-yielding fruit—to you it shall be for food." Many scholars see the Torah as thereby pointing to vegetarianism as an ideal, as [[Adam and Eve]] did not partake of the flesh of animals as all humans and animals were originally commanded by God to only eat plants.<ref name=kook>{{cite journal |last=Kook |first=Avraham Yitzhak |author= |authorlink=Avraham Yitzhak Kook|last2= |first2= |author2= |authorlink2= |date= |year=1961 |month= |title=A Vision of Vegetarianism and Peace |trans-title= |journal= |volume= |series= |issue= |page= |pages= |at= |chapter= |location= |publisher= |editor1-first=David |editor1-last=Cohen |editor1-link=David Cohen (rabbi) |language= |arxiv= |id= |isbn= |issn= |oclc= |pmid= |pmc= |bibcode= |doi= |accessdate= |url=http://jewishveg.com/AVisionofVegetarianismandPeace.pdf |laysource= |laysummary= |laydate= |quote= |ref= |separator= |postscript= }}</ref> According to some interpretations, God's original plan was for mankind to be vegetarian, and God only later gave permission for man to eat meat in a [[Noahic Covenant|covenant with Noah]] (Genesis 9:1–17) as a temporary concession because of Man's weak nature. This concessionary view of meat-consumption is based on the scriptural analysis of several [[Rishonim]].<ref name="Schwartz, Richard H 2001. pp. 1, 12">Schwartz, Richard H. Judaism and Vegetarianism. Lantern Books. New York, 2001. pp. 1, 12, 16, 19, 188. {{ISBN|1-930051-24-7}}.</ref>
The Torah gives precise details on how animals are to be sacrificed and slaughtered (''[[shechita]]''). According to Rabbis [[Shlomo Ephraim Luntschitz]] and [[Abraham Isaac Kook]] the complexity of these laws were intended to discourage the consumption of meat.<ref>"The Vision of Eden: Animal Welfare and Vegetarianism" in "Jewish Law and Mysticism", Orot 2003</ref> ''[[Kashrut]]'' may also be designed to remind Jews of the magnitude of the task undertaken in killing a living being.<ref name="Kalechofsky, Roberta 1995. pp. 16, 54">Kalechofsky, Roberta. Rabbis and Vegetarianism: An Evolving Tradition. Micah Publications. Massachusetts, 1995. pp. 16, 54, 55, 65, 66, 68, 70, 71. {{ISBN|0-916288-42-0}}.</ref>
Some writers assert that the Jewish prophet [[Isaiah]] was a vegetarian, on the basis of passages in the [[Book of Isaiah]] that extol nonviolence and reverence for life, such as Isaiah 1:11, 11:6-9, 65:25, and 66:3. Some of these writers refer to "the vegetarian Isaiah",<ref>{{cite web|title= Religious Quotes |website= [[Animal Liberation Front]] |url= http://www.animalliberationfront.com/Practical/Shop--ToDo/Religion/ReligiousQuotes.htm |accessdate= 2016-04-01 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150922130647/http://www.animalliberationfront.com/Practical/Shop--ToDo/Religion/ReligiousQuotes.htm |archivedate= 2015-09-22 |deadurl= no |quote= Isaiah is ... the prophet with the most references to nonviolence and universal respect for life. ... Jesus refers to the vegetarian Isaiah more than to any other.}}</ref> "the notorious vegetarian Isaiah",<ref>{{cite web |title=The Biblical Basis of Veganism |publisher=The Nazarenes of Mount Carmel |location=[[Cincinnati]], [[Ohio]] |url=http://www.essene.com/Bible/BiblicalBasisOfVeganism.html |accessdate=2016-04-01 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6gd6BSxNE?url=http://www.essene.com/Bible/BiblicalBasisOfVeganism.html |archivedate=2016-04-09 |deadurl=no |quote=the notorious vegetarian Isaiah |df= }}</ref> and "Isaiah, the vegetarian prophet".<ref>{{cite journal |last= Braunstein |first= Mark Mathew |authorlink= Mark Mathew Braunstein |title= Vegetarianism in Art |journal= [[Vegetarian Times]] |issue= #40 |page= 24 |date= September 1980 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=JwcAAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA24&lpg=PA24&dq=%22Isaiah,+the+vegetarian+prophet%22&source=bl&ots=TDbQcfvq-d&sig=kU8MgZ6RF_aOoIOM0a98q64Z6BU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi8ibfqh-3LAhWFKh4KHQDMDSUQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=%22Isaiah%2C%20the%20vegetarian%20prophet%22&f=false |quote= Isaiah, the vegetarian prophet, meant also that humans must sit with the lamb, the kid, the ox -- because humans must make peace with the animals before they can make peace with other humans.}}</ref>
The pious Jewish youths [[Daniel (biblical figure)|Daniel]], [[Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego]] became vegan according to the Bible story found in [[Book of Daniel|Daniel]] 1:8-16. At Daniel's request, the four boys were subjected to a test; they were fed vegetables and water for ten days. At the end of the ten days, the four boys were in better condition than the other boys who ate a non-vegan diet. Consequently, they remained on the vegan diet after the test concluded.<ref>{{cite web |last=Sardi |first=Bill |title=Vegetarian Diet |website=Bible for Health |url=http://bibleforhealth.com/index.asp?story=vegetarian%20diet |accessdate=2016-04-01 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6gbrxFfiM?url=http://bibleforhealth.com/index.asp?story%3Dvegetarian%20diet |archivedate=2016-04-08 |deadurl=no |quote=And so the boys continued to eat vegetables, and exhibited unusual intelligence and the king favored them in his service. |df= }}</ref>
According to [[Clement of Alexandria]], [[Matthew the Apostle]] was a vegetarian. Clement wrote: "Matthew partook of seeds, and nuts, and vegetables, without flesh."<ref>{{cite book|author= Clement of Alexandria |authorlink= Clement of Alexandria |title= The Instructor |year= 1994 |orig-year= c. 198 |volume= Book II, Chapter I -- On Eating |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=DPwQDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT67&lpg=PT67&dq=%22Matthew+partook+of+seeds,+and+nuts,+and+vegetables,+without+flesh.%22&source=bl&ots=kz8hTO8gs9&sig=_8HrfAxAPprdvZzz4SB-5iOCQE4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiX6L-l7szOAhUH6WMKHSstD8I4ChDoAQgeMAE#v=onepage&q=%22Matthew%20partook%20of%20seeds%2C%20and%20nuts%2C%20and%20vegetables%2C%20without%20flesh.%22&f=false |publisher= Aeterna Press |location= [[London]] |quote= Matthew partook of seeds, and nuts, and vegetables, without flesh.}}</ref> [[James (brother of Jesus)|James the brother of Jesus of Nazareth]] was said to have been vegetarian. As [[Eusebius]] puts it quoting [[Hegesippus (chronicler)|Hegesippus]]: "[James] drank no wine or other intoxicating liquor, nor did he eat flesh."<ref>{{cite web|title= Hegesippus (Roberts-Donaldson translation) |url= http://www.earlychristianwritings.com/text/hegesippus.html |website= Early Christian Writings |publisher= Peter Kirby |quote= James, the Lord's brother, ... drank no wine or other intoxicating liquor, nor did he eat flesh}}</ref> Hegesippus also stated that James did not wear wool, but only linen.
A number of ancient Jewish sects, including early Karaite sects, regarded the eating of meat as prohibited as long as Zion was in ruins and Israel in exile.<ref>Encyclopaedia Judaica, Second Edition, Volume 11, p. 788</ref>
A number of medieval scholars of [[Judaism]], such as [[Joseph Albo]] and [[Isaac Arama]], regard vegetarianism as a moral ideal, not out of a concern for [[animal welfare]] per se but out of a concern for the moral character of the slaughterer.<ref name="innernet1">{{cite book|url=http://www.innernet.org.il/article.php?aid=107 |title=Contemporary Halakhic Problems |volume=3 |last=Bleich |first=J. David |authorlink=J. David Bleich|publisher=KTAV Publishing House |year=1989 |deadurl= yes |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120518014142/http://www.innernet.org.il/article.php?aid=107 |archive-date= 2012-05-18 |quote=A number of medieval scholars regard vegetarianism as a moral ideal, not because of a concern for the welfare of animals, but because of the fact that the slaughter of animals might cause the individual who performs such acts to develop negative character traits, viz., meanness and cruelty}}</ref> Rabbeinu [[Asher ben Meshullam]] (twelfth century theologian and Talmudic scholar, son of [[Meshullam ben Jacob]])) was said to have never tasted meat.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ginzberg|first1=Louis|last2=Kohler|first2=Kaufmann|title=ASHER B. MESHULLAM|url=http://jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/1937-asher-b-meshullam|website=jewishencyclopedia.com}}</ref>
==Modern Jewish Vegetarianism==
===Modern-day proponents=== [[Image:Sirjonathansacks.jpg|thumb|right|Rabbi Jonathan Sacks.]] While most modern-day Jews are not vegetarian, a number of prominent rabbis have advocated vegetarianism or veganism. In 2017, a statement by [[Jewish Veg]] encouraging veganism for all Jews was signed by notable rabbis including [[Jonathan Wittenberg]], [[Daniel Sperber]], [[David Wolpe]], [[Nathan Lopes Cardozo]], [[Kerry Olitzky]], [[Shmuly Yanklowitz]], [[Aryeh Cohen]], [[Geoffrey Claussen]], [[Rami M. Shapiro]], [[David Rosen (rabbi)|David Rosen]], [[Raysh Weiss]], [[Elyse Goldstein]], [[Shefa Gold]], and [[Yonassan Gershom]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.jewishveg.org/rabbinic-statement|title=Rabbinic Statement|work=Jewish Veg|access-date=2018-04-25|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://vegnews.com/articles/page.do?pageId=10149&catId=1|title=74 Rabbis Urge Jewish Community to Go Vegan|work=VegNews.com|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> Other notable rabbis who have promoted vegetarianism have included [[David Cohen (rabbi)|David Cohen]] (known as "Ha-Nazir"), [[Shlomo Goren]], [[Irving Greenberg]], [[Jeremy Gimpel]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tabletmag.com/jewish-life-and-religion/197361/life-after-brisket|title=The Rise of Israel’s Orthodox Vegan Movement – Tablet Magazine|website=www.tabletmag.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-25}}</ref> [[Asa Keisar]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.jpost.com/Magazine/The-halachic-case-for-veganism-432808|title=The (halachic) case for veganism|work=The Jerusalem Post {{!}} JPost.com|access-date=2018-05-10}}</ref> [[Jonathan Sacks]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rabbisacks.org/faith-lectures-the-messianic-idea-today/|title=Faith Lectures: The Messianic Idea Today|last=Sacks|first=Jonathan|authorlink=Jonathan Sacks|date=2001-06-06|accessdate=2016-08-19|quote=But I can't say very much about chickens because I'm a vegetarian and I stay milchik all the time.}}</ref> [[She'ar Yashuv Cohen]], and [[Yitzhak HaLevi Herzog]], [[Everett Gendler]], [[Joseph B. Soloveitchik|Joseph Soloveitchik]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kolhamevaser.com/vegetarianism-and-judaism-the-ravs-radical-view/|title=Vegetarianism and Judaism: The Rav’s Radical View|date=2012-02-08|work=Kol Hamevaser|access-date=2018-04-25|language=en-US}}</ref> and [[Abraham Isaac Kook]]. While Kook was not completely vegetarian, [[David Cohen (rabbi)|David Cohen]] wrote an influential essay, ''A Vision of Vegetarianism and Peace'' (first published in installments in 1903–04) summarizing Kook's ideas about the "coming of the new society" in which humankind becomes vegan.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/AVisionOfVegetarianismAndPeace/AVisionOfVegetarianismAndPeace_djvu.txt |title=Full text of "A Vision of Vegetarianism and Peace" |website=Archive.org |date=1985-04-20 |accessdate=2016-01-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=A Vision of Vegetarianism and Peace|url=http://www.jewishveg.com/DSvision.html|publisher=Jewish Vegetarians of North America}}</ref>
Other notable Jewish vegetarians include [[Shmuel Yosef Agnon]], [[Isaac Bashevis Singer#Vegetarianism|Isaac Bashevis Singer]], [[Reuven Rivlin]], [[Franz Kafka]], [[Richard H. Schwartz]], [[Jonathan Safran Foer]], [[Aaron Gross|Aaron S. Gross]], and [[Roberta Kalechofsky]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q0D_7wbjCv0C&pg=PA186&lpg=#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Animals and World Religions: Rightful Relations |volume= |author=Lisa Kemmerer |page=186|authorlink=|publisher= |year=2012}}</ref>
The first Jewish-vegetarian cookbook has been compiled by [[Fania Lewando]] and was first published in 1938 in [[Vilnius]].<ref>Lithuanian Jewish Community: ''[https://www.lzb.lt/en/2016/08/08/a-jewish-culinary-legend-reborn-fania-lewandos-vilnius/ A Jewish Culinary Legend Reborn: Fania Lewando’s Vilnius]'', consulted 14. Juli 2018</ref> An English translation was issued in 2015.
A number of groups promote Jewish vegetarianism:
*The Jewish Vegetarians of North America (JVNA) was founded by Jonathan Wolf in 1975 to promote vegetarianism within the Judaic tradition.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zo5TqKQVcEgC&pg=PA167&lpg=#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Judaism and Vegetarianism|author=Richard H. Schwartz|year=2001|pages=167–170}}</ref> JVNA produced the 2007 film ''[[A Sacred Duty]]'' under leadership of Professor Emeritus [[Richard H. Schwartz]], then president of JVNA. In October 2015, JVNA changed its name to [[Jewish Veg]]. *The Shamayim V'Aretz Institute led by Rabbi [[Shmuly Yanklowitz]] promotes a vegan diet in the Jewish community through animal welfare activism, kosher veganism, and Jewish spirituality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shamayimvaretz.org |title=The Shamayim V'Aretz Institute | מכון שמים וארץ - Home |website=Shamayimvaretz.org |date= |accessdate=2016-01-07}}</ref> *The Jewish Vegetarian Society (JVS) was co-founded (briefly as the Jewish Vegetarian and Natural Health Society, before the name was abbreviated) by Vivien and Philip Pick in the 1960s with the aim of promoting a kinder society without killing animals for food.<ref>{{cite book|title=Judaism and Vegetarianism |author=Richard H. Schwartz |pages=159–161 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zo5TqKQVcEgC&pg=PA159&lpg=#v=onepage&q&f=false| year=2001}}</ref> Philip Pick was the first chairman of the organisation, with Maurice Norman Lester the first vice chairman and his wife Carole Lester its first secretary. *[[Amirim]], an Israeli vegetarian ''[[moshav]]'' (village), was founded in 1958. The founders of Amirim were motivated to create a vegetarian village because of their love for animals and concern for animal rights, as well as for health reasons. Both religious and non-religious families live at Amirim.<ref>https://our-compass.org/2013/05/30/amirim-israel-the-worlds-first-vegan-village</ref> *The "Concern for Helping Animals in Israel (CHAI)" animal welfare organization promotes Jewish vegetarianism;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chai.org.il/en/compassion/judaism/heritage_judaism_veg.htm|title=excerpt from the article "Judaism and Vegetarianism"|last=Schwartz|first=Richard|accessdate=April 15, 2013}}</ref> CHAI's building project is named the Isaac Bashevis Singer Humane Education Center.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chai.org.il/en/humane/humane_singer_i.htm|title=I.B. Singer Humane Education Center|website=CHAI|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714115123/http://www.chai.org.il/en/humane/humane_singer_i.htm|archive-date=2014-07-14|deadurl=yes|quote=... construction on the Isaac Bashevis Singer Humane Education Center, on the grounds of the SPCA in Tel Aviv-Jaffa, is at last set to begin.}}</ref> *Behemla is a [[Haredi Judaism|Haredi]] organization that advocates against animal cruelty and promotes veganism.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Thousands-flock-to-Ramat-Gan-for-worlds-largest-vegan-festival-378796|title=In for some vegan shoes or vegan condoms?|work=The Jerusalem Post {{!}} JPost.com|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite described as a Jewish vegetarian organization.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zo5TqKQVcEgC&pg=PA165&dq=%22anonymous+for+animal+rights%22|title=Judaism and Vegetarianism|last=Schwartz|first=Richard H.|date=2001|publisher=Lantern Books|year=|isbn=9781930051249|location=|pages=165|language=en}}</ref> *Vegan Friendly is an organization in [[Tel Aviv]] that works to make veganism mainstream,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vegan-friendly.co.il|title=Vegan-Friendly {{!}} משדרגים את התרבות הטבעונית the vegan celebration of Jewish holidays.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vegan-friendly.co.il/blog/category/1/Holidays_Events|title=Vegan-Friendly {{!}} חגים ואירועים|website=www.vegan-friendly.co.il|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
Jewish vegetarianism and veganism have become especially popular among Israeli Jews. In 2016, Israel was described as "the most vegan country on Earth," as five percent of its population eschewed all animal products. That number had more than doubled since 2010, when only 2.6 percent of Israelis were either vegan or vegetarian.<ref>Rachel Frazin, "[http://www.thetower.org/article/how-israel-became-the-global-center-of-veganism How Israel Became the Global Center of Veganism"]," September 2016, Retrieved 2018-03-26.</ref> Veganism is particularly popular in the city of Tel Aviv, which has been described as the "vegan capital of the world."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/middle-east/vegan-food-tel-aviv-best-restaurants-israel-vegetarian-friendly-port-capital-meshek-barzilay-orna-a8036081.html|title=This is the vegan capital of the world|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-06-18|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/249402/tel-aviv-crowned-worlds-vegan-capital|title=Tel Aviv Crowned World's Vegan Capital – Tablet Magazine|website=www.tabletmag.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-18}}</ref>
Interest in veganism and vegetarianism has grown among Israel's diverse Jewish populations, including among secular Jews and Orthodox Jews.<ref name="Tablet Magazine">{{Cite news|url=http://www.tabletmag.com/jewish-life-and-religion/197361/life-after-brisket|title=The Rise of Israel’s Orthodox Vegan Movement|work=Tablet Magazine|access-date=2018-03-26|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/17/there-is-no-kosher-meat-the-israelis-full-of-zeal-for-going-vegan|title='There is no kosher meat': the Israelis full of zeal for going vegan|last=Holmes|first=Oliver|date=2018-03-17|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> The Israeli rabbi Asa Keisar is a rare example of an Orthodox rabbi who has argued that eating meat and animal byproducts is no longer permitted according to Jewish sources, because of the cruelty inflicted on animals.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.yediot.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4861831,00.html|title="לגרוס אפרוחים בני יומם בשביל כסף? זו לא יהדות"|date=2016-10-02|work=ynet|access-date=2018-06-18|language=he}}</ref> It is more common for Orthodox rabbis to call on Jews to reduce their consumption of animal products, as when a consortium of 120 Orthodox rabbis scholars, and community leaders in Jerusalem, known as Beit Hillel, issued a paper calling on Jews to reduce meat consumption in order to alleviate animal suffering.<ref name="Tablet Magazine"/>
===Ethical Arguments=== There are several religious and philosophical arguments used by modern Jewish vegetarians regarding the [[ethics of eating meat]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jewishveg.com/torah.html|title=Judaism and Vegetarianism - A Vegetarian View of the Torah|date=|website=Jewishveg.com|accessdate=2016-01-07}}</ref> According to some, [[vegetarianism]] is consistent with the sacred teachings and highest ideals of [[Judaism]], including [[compassion]], [[health]], [[life]], [[conservation of resources]], [[tzedakah]], [[kashrut]], [[peace]], and [[justice]]. In contrast, the mass production and consumption of meat and other animal products contradicts many [[Jewish values]] and teachings, gravely harming people, animals, communities, and the environment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brook.com/jveg|title=The Vegetarian Mitzvah|author=Dan Brook, Ph.D.}}</ref>
One ''[[mitzvah]]'' cited by vegetarians is ''[[tza'ar ba'alei hayyim]]''; the injunction not to cause "pain to living creatures."<ref name="Kalechofsky, Roberta 1995. pp. 16, 54" /> The laws of ''[[shechita]]'' are meant to prevent the suffering of animals. However, [[factory farming]] and high-speed mechanized kosher [[slaughterhouse]]s have been criticized for failing to meet the essence of shechita. [[Jonathan Safran Foer]] narrated the short documentary film ''If This Is Kosher...'', which records what he considers abuses within the kosher [[meat industry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rf1eLjnGafk|title=If This Is Kosher…|last=Foer|first=Jonathan Safran|publisher=YouTube}}</ref>
Another mitzvah often cited by Jewish vegetarians is ''[[bal tashchit]]''; the law which prohibits waste.<ref name="Kalechofsky, Roberta 1995. pp. 16, 54"/> They suggest that an [[Omnivore|omnivorous]] diet is wasteful, since it uses 5 times more grain, 10 times more water, 15 times more land and 20 times more energy when compared to a [[veganism|vegan]] diet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reformjudaism.org.uk/bal-tashchit/|title=Bal tashchit ('do not destroy')|date=2016-02-24|website=Reformjudaism.org.uk|accessdate=2016-08-19|quote=... an omnivorous diet (one that includes meat) is wasteful and should be prohibited, since an omnivorous diet uses five times as much grain, over ten times as much water, over 15 times as much land and over 20 times as much energy as compared with a vegan diet.}}</ref>
Some Jewish vegetarians also stress the commandment to maintain one's health and not harm oneself (''venishmartem me'od lenafshoteichem''), and point to [[Veganism#Health arguments|research]] indicating that following a [[Vegetarianism|vegetarian diet]] promotes better health.<ref>Richard Schwartz, "Jewish Teachings on Health," https://www.jewishveg.org/schwartz/jhealth1.html</ref> Jewish vegetarians have also argued for [[environmental vegetarianism]], pointing out that [[global warming]], [[hunger]] and the depletion of [[natural resource]]s can be lessened by a global shift to a vegetarian or vegan diet.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2010/jun/02/un-report-meat-free-diet|title=UN urges global move to meat and dairy-free diet|author=Felicity Carus|date=2 June 2010|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>Richard Schwartz, "Jewish Environmental Teachings," https://www.jewishveg.org/schwartz/jenviro.html</ref>
===Opposition to Jewish Vegetarianism=== Some Orthodox rabbis have argued that it is forbidden for an individual to become a vegetarian if they do so because they believe in animal rights, but have ruled that vegetarianism is allowed for pragmatic reasons (if kosher meat is expensive or hard to come by in their area), health concerns, or for reasons of personal taste (if someone finds meat unpalatable).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.aish.com/ci/s/48916842.html|title=Judaism and Vegetarianism|work=aishcom|access-date=2018-03-26|language=en}}</ref> Some believe that [[halakha]] encourages the eating of meat at the Sabbath and Festival meals; thus some Orthodox Jews who are otherwise vegetarian will nevertheless consume meat at these meals.{{Citation needed|date=September 2007}}

'''Johann Heinrich Abicht''' (4 May 1762 – 28 April 1816) was a [[Germany|German]] philosopher.
==Biography== Abicht was born at {{Interlanguage link multi|Volkstedt|de|3=Volkstedt (Rudolstadt)|lt=Volkstedt}} (now part of [[Rudolstadt]]). His grandfather was teacher and organist in [[Wilmersdorf, Gehren]], and his father was a teacher in Volkstedt. Johann Abicht himself finished the college in Rudolstadt and visited the [[University of Erlangen]] in 1781. In 1784 he became controller at the house of chief equerry von Schall in [[Öhringen]]. Abicht made his magister in 1786 and his doctor in philosophy in 1790. In the same year, he was appointed adjunct and then extraordinary professor in the philosophical faculty. He became regular professor in 1796. On 4 August 1804 he was appointed professor of logic and metaphysics at the newly reorganised [[Vilnius University|university of Wilna]]. He died at [[Wilna]], aged 53.
His philosophy is clearly influenced by [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]], later by [[Karl Leonhard Reinhold]].
==Publications== * ''De philosophiae Kantianae ad theologiam habitu'', 1788 * ''Versuch einer Metaphysik des Vergnügens nach Kantischen Grundsätzen zur Grundlegung einer systematischen Thelematologie und Moral'', 1789 * ''Philosophie der Erkenntnisse'', 1791 * ''Hermias, oder Auflösung der die gültige Elementarphilosophie betreffenden Aenesidemischen Zweifel'', 1794 * ''Neues philosophisches Magazin zur Erläuterung und Anwendung des Kantischen Systems'', 1789–1790, collaboration with {{Interlanguage link multi|Friedrich Gottlob Born|de}}. * ''Philosophisches Journal'', 4 volumes, 1794–1795, collaboration
==Sources== * ''Allgemeine Deutsche Biographie'' - [[s:de:ADB:Abicht, Johann Heinr.|online version]] at [[Wikisource]]
